title: Milton Jarvie
text:
Milton Livingstone Fredericks Jarvie, (12 July 1891 – 31 January 1965) was an Australian politician, businessman and soldier.
Jarvie was born at <a href="Pyramul%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Pyramul</a>, south of <a href="Mudgee%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Mudgee, New South Wales</a>, to schoolteacher John Rose Shaw Jarvie and Jean Wade, "née" Fredericks. He attended <a href="Enmore%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Enmore</a> High School and the <a href="University%20of%20Sydney">University of Sydney</a>, receiving a Diploma of Economics. Around 1914 he married Geraldine James. From 1915 to 1920 he served in the <a href="First%20Australian%20Imperial%20Force">Australian Imperial Force</a>'s Provost Corps in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, rising to the rank of <a href="major%20%28rank%29">major</a> and being decorated with the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a>. For his later service with the <a href="Australian%20Army%20Reserve">Citizens Military Force</a>, Jarvie received the <a href="Efficiency%20Decoration">Efficiency Decoration</a>. After the war he became a business manager and an executive officer with the <a href="British-Australasian%20Tobacco%20Company">British Australasian Tobacco Company</a>. In 1925 he was elected to <a href="Marrickville%20Council">Marrickville Council</a>, on which he served until 1927 (he was also mayor in 1927).
In 1925, Jarvie was elected to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Legislative%20Assembly">New South Wales Legislative Assembly</a> as one of the <a href="Nationalist%20Party%20of%20Australia">Nationalist</a> members for <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Western%20Suburbs">Western Suburbs</a>. When single-member districts were re-introduced in 1927 he represented <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Ashfield">Ashfield</a>, holding the seat until 1935, when he lost <a href="United%20Australia%20Party">United Australia Party</a> preselection. Jarvie contested the election unsuccessfully as an <a href="Independent%20politician">independent</a>. From 1937 he was an executive officer with the Sound Proof Company, and during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> he served as war area officer for Southern New South Wales. After the war (1945–47), he was director of the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, Displaced Persons Camp in southern Austria. He married Helen Michell in 1949. Jarvie died in 1965 at <a href="Concord%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Concord, New South Wales</a>.
